Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: DNA Discrimination Using the Synthetic Hybrid Nanopore
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project proposes to develop a new robust nanopore platform for direct DNA sequencing. Nanopore methodology offers the potential for a significantly improved approach for DNA sequencing by having an inherent capability of very long data reads that are not compromised by insertions or deletions. In addition, by operating in the single molecule regime, nanopores require minimal consumables, sample quantities, sample preparation, and no amplification. However, the stability of current nanopore sensor platforms has limited their potential. As such, a more robust nanopore is needed. During this project, a highly-stable, reproducibly sized nanopore that is ideally suited for low-noise, high-bandwidth DNA sequencing applications, will be designed and fabricated. The improvement in robustness over current nanopore technology will allow examination of voltage regimes, which previously have not been able to be used in conjunction with nanopores.

The broader impact/commercial potential of this project is the fabrication of a low-cost, easy-to-use, DNA sequencing system that provides highly accurate short reads. Inexpensive sequencing has the potential to dramatically enhance biological, medical, pharmaceutical, and biochemical research, by improving ability to quickly gather and analyze genetic information. This project will contribute greatly to the improvement of current nanopore sensor technology, making advanced DNA sequencing capabilities, with reduced operating times and costs, available to more researchers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The use of a nanopore to directly sequence single stranded DNA (ssDNA) is an intriguing concept. If successful, nanopore based DNA sequencing would allow for rapid (< 24 hours) and inexpensive (~$1,000) genome sequencing. Inexpensive sequencing has the potential to dramatically enhance biological, medical, pharmaceutical and biochemical research. In addition, nanopore sequencing would enhance a scientist’s or physician’s ability to quickly gather and analyze genetic information. These advances offer the potential for a physician to determine what genetic diseases a patient is or is not predisposed to have, if environmental factors have altered a patient’s genetic makeup in ways that would likely result in abnormalities (e.g. cancer) and how diseases are spreading through local populations. However, various challenges such as platform stability, nucleotide resolution and spatial control have prevented researchers from directly sequencing ssDNA using a nanopore.

During this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project, Electronic BioSciences (EBS) proposed to create a novel and robust nanopore platform for direct DNA sequencing applications. During this project, EBS was to complete a research and development phase that would end in a proof-of-concept demonstration of the nanopore device.  In addition, concepts for transitioning device production to a mass fabrication phase in the most cost efficient manner were to be investigated during the program.

Over the course of this program, EBS was able to produce 30 base platforms for nanopore device development, meeting the originally proposed project goal. These base platforms were fully characterized and a standard process for future platform fabrication was developed. Once these base platforms were created, protocols for converting these platforms into the complete nanopore devices capable of directly sequencing ssDNA were developed. In addition to the development of these production protocols, custom chemicals that were required for the creation of the nanopore devices were developed and manufactured by an outside vendor.

Upon completion of the program, EBS was in the final stages of successfully fabricating the first robust nanopore device capable of identifying individual bases on a strand of ssDNA. Although time limitations were encountered for converting the base platforms into the complete nanopore devices, there are no foreseeable obstacles to finish the complete fabrication process.  EBS will thus continue working towards the development and full characterization of a novel and robust nanopore platform capable of single nucleotide discrimination and ultimately complete genome sequencing.
